data.title: Don't crach when OpenGL version is unsupported
data.body: Add `exit(1)` to properly close with error.

data.title: Add compatibility with old OpenGL 2.1 drivers
data.body:
If ARB_framebuffer_object is not supported, try to fall-back to
EXT_framebuffer_object if present.

In current version of godot, the way framebuffers are used is backward
compatible with the older EXT_framebuffer_object extension.

Fixes #6591
Done with SuperUserNameMan

data.title: Add CC parameter to allow use of custom C compiler
data.body:
Hi,

Currently we can only customize the C++ compiler with the `CXX` option and the C compiler sticks to `gcc` no matter what.
This small patch provide the `CC` option in the SConscruct to fix this ;-)

data.title: Custom resources can't be saved when edited by plugin
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 64-bits. Recent master build.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm creating an editor for my custom resource, but when trying to use `ResourceSave.save()` with the object received in `edit()` the resource is not saved and there's an error in console:

```
ERROR: _ResourceSaver::save: Condition ' p_resource.is_null() ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER
   At: core\bind\core_bind.cpp:134
```

Saving the resource from the inspector works.

Also, testing for `object extends Resource` returns `true`, so it is actually is a Resource, but the reference is lost somehow in the process, so the `save()` method receives a null reference and gives the error.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a plugin with a custom resource.
- Create a new resource of that type from the inspector.
- Try to save the custom resource using `ResourceSaver.save()` with the object received from `edit()` method.
- See errors in console and file not saved.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[custom-resource.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/491475/custom-resource.zip)

This project has a sample plugin already enabled. Create a new `CustomResource` from the Inspector then click on the **Save** button on the top-right toolbar. There'll be an OS alert and the error will show in console.

data.title: Changing a node type in editor does not remove signal connections
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 64-bits. Recent master build.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When changing a `LineEdit` to a `Control` I got an infinite stream of the following error:

```
ERROR: Object::emit_signal: Error calling method from signal 'timeout': 'Control::_toggle_draw_caret': Method not found.
   At: core\object.cpp:1278
```

It turns out a `LineEdit` control connects a timeout signal to its `_toggle_draw_caret` (obviously to draw the caret blinking) but never disconnects it when changing the node to another type. So now it wants to call the function in the new node, which does not have such function.

This is solved by deleting the node.

Something similar happens if you change one control for another:

```
ERROR: Disconnecting nonexistent signal 'size_changed', slot: 48438:_size_changed
   At: core\object.cpp:1559
ERROR: Signal 'size_changed'' already connected to given method '_size_changed' in that object.
   At: core\object.cpp:1499
```

It seems the code is trying to disconnect the signal but failing to do so for some reason.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Add a `LineEdit` node.
- Right-click and select "Change Type".
- Select any other node type.
- See the errors in console.

data.title: HighDPI mode is scaling too much on high resolution display (Windows)
data.body:
Godot 2.1 / Windows 10 on a Surface Pro 3

Not quite sure if this fits into any of the existing issues, so I'm creating a new one. I tried out Godot 2.1 on a Surface today and by default (Auto) it uses the LowDPI mode. In that mode, everything is blurry. When I turn on HighDPI, everything is far too large, it is pretty much unusable.

![godot-size](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3977620/18810273/77bc82ba-8292-11e6-864e-bf474e1a023a.JPG)

To give some more information: I am using 150% text size on Windows, which is the default for the Surface. The resolution is 2160x1440 on a 12 inch display.

data.title: Patch9Sprite Node (70% finished)
data.body:
This PR is not ocmplete, please do not merge yet. I have it open so everyone can follow the development and make contributions.

Roadmap:
- [x] Create a new Node class as a copy of Sprite.
- [x] Remove unused properties (centered, frames, and region).
- [x] Add Margin and Patch9Policy properties.
- [x] Implement Drawing in all 5 Patch Policies.
- [x] Add a Size property, since using scale looks like a bad way to handle this
- [x] Add icons
- [x] Make sure FlipH, FlipV and negative scales works properly
- [x] Documentation
- [ ] Create EditorPlugins to make development easier (edit size, margins and ~~pivot~~)

data.title: Naming conventions
data.body:
This is related to #6523, I opened a separate issue as it might be long (? or not...). Anyway, naming conventions, this is what I have:
- member variables (properties & such): only nouns
- methods: verb (present tense), verb + nous, just like the usual: `get_position` for example & the verb should go first always
- signals: verb (that describes state) / verb + nouns, for example instead of `enter_tree` have `entering_tree` (if it's fired before doing the action) and `entered_tree` if triggers after the task has finished (it has already entered), just like the methods, it should go first. For examples `script_changed` would become `changed_script`.

Also I think GDScript should only offer one of two options or both, but be complete:
- either access a member variable (or property) directly and change it, for example `transoform.origin.x = some_new_value`
- or only through `set_`, `get_` methods, like `set_pos()`, `get_pos()`

By complete I mean have all properties be directly accessible and settable through the first option and have them accessible through `set_`, `get_`. Also if then something like `transform.origin.x += 1` would be allowed (by the way, in this example `transform` would be a Godot object), then we should have the ability in GDScript to have a "magic" method to create our own `+=`, `-=` etc. compatible objects (like in Python)

data.title: Tool Mode - Export vars stop working in inspector when setget is used.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 8 - Godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I've been trying to test simple export vars with setters and getters in a tool mode script.  Once tool is added, or the setget function is referenced, the export variable is no longer able to be modified in the Inspector.  Regardless of restarting the project.

When I try to change the value, the console just says "Set <the variable name here>"

I've tested all sorts of output methods just to see if the function was at least being triggered, it isn't, unless something else modified the variable.

Now the code is simply what I have below, and still the variables are frozen and aren't able to be modified in the Inspector:

```
tool
extends Node2D

export var visible = true setget toggle

func toggle(value):
    pass

func _ready():
    pass
```

data.title: [Discusion] New Patch9Sprite Node
data.body:
Hi, i'll start to work in a series of features i've been thinking for many time, first one is Patch9 support for sprites, i have talked with @reduz about this in the past, but i don't remember too much of the idea i had back then.

Basically, the idea is to add a new node similar Sprite with an enum. The enum is called PatchPolicy and changes the way the 9 patch is rendered, i have 5 policies in mind:

```
enum Patch9Policy {
    PATCH9_NONE,
    PATCH9_EXPAND,
    PATCH9_TILE,
    PATCH9_TILE_SHRINK,
    PATCH9_TILE_EXPAND
};
```

The new properties are the PatchPolicy and the 4 margins of the texture, same way as StyleBoxImage and Patch9Frame control.
At the same time i'll remove some useless properties:
~~Centered~~ (will be the default)
~~Vframes~~ (unused)
~~Hframes~~ (unused)
~~Frame~~ (unused)
~~Region~~ (unused)
~~Region Rect~~ (unused)
Instead of using Regions We'll encourage people to use the already available AtlasTexture, since now it's much easier to edit thx to the Texture Region editor.

So, what do you think of it as is? do you see any of these policies useless? any other policy to add?

I'll try to make a mockup of how every policy looks like so it's more clear.

[EDIT]: I just added a Pull Request related to this development
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/6600

data.title: Importer creates animation tracks even for non-animated vertex groups
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Debian GNU/Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I have a model created in Blender with Actions. Some actions don't involve certain bones (clothing); this is on purpose, they will be modified via GDScript dynamically in the game based on kinematics.

However, Godot importer creates a track in all animations for such bones nevertheless (with two keys: one at the beginning and one at the end of the animation, both in the default position of the bone). This interferes with the in-game kinematic based control. 

A possible workaround is to remove all such tracks manually by hand or using an import script. 

To be clear, the bones I'm referring to are supposed deform the mesh (mainly for clothing and hair).

I expect Godot to import the track/keyframe structure as-is from Blender, and not insert additional tracks and keyframes on its own.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a model in Blender and create an action, but don't create tracks for all bones. Export using Better Collada and use Godot's scene importer.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Pattern matching (switch) for GDScript
data.body:
I'd like to suggest adding pattern matching to GDScript and I would be willing to implement it.

As of now, GDScript doesn't feature a `switch` statement - you have to chain multiple if statements.

_(All the syntax here is just a first sketch, suggestions welcome)_
# Pattern matching

Pattern matching is the inspection of the structure and contents of a value to branch execution.

So for simple values (like numbers, strings) it acts like a switch statment.

``` GDScript
var num = 42
match num:
    0:  print("Zero")
    23: print("Half way there")
    42: print("The answer")
```

The difference to a `switch` statement is that those cases can be nested. You can match on the contents of an array for example.

``` GDScript
var array = [13, "37", ["test", "array"]]
match array:
    [13, "37", ["test", "array"]]: print("Wow, a perfect match!")
    [13, 37, ..]:                  print("l33t man") # .. matches the rest of the array
    []:                            print("empty array")
```

~~Matching on a dictionary would work the same, except that matching on keys wouldn't be possible.~~
Dictionaries would be matched on the key **and** the value. 
## Deconstructing values

Instead of simply branching depending on the equality of values it would be possible to bind new variables.

When the first pattern that matches the value is encountered the corresponding branch will be executed. If a pattern doesn't match the next one is tried. So the *more general patterns should be defined beneath the more specific.

To bind a new variable you would simply write a new identifier instead of a value.

``` GDScript
var array = [13, "37", ["test", "array"]]
match array:
    [13, "37", [var a, var b]]: print(a, ", ", b) # a = "test", b = "array"
    var n:                      print("Unknown array structure: " + str(n))
```

When matching dictionaries only the value would be bindable. e.g. `{"test": var a}`

Just matching on a new identifier is equal to the `default` case in `switch`-statements.

**_Let me know what you think**_ :blush:

data.title: AnimationEditor: zoom using ctrl+wheel
data.body: closes #6585

data.title: Godot is not compatible with OpenGL 2.1, but it should be compatible
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Godot 2.1 official / custom build from GIT; Windows 7; old Intel graphics which supports OpenGL 2.1:

```
Mobile Intel(R) 4 Series Express Chipset Family from Intel
OpenGL version 2.1.0 - Build 8.15.10.2869 is supported
```

It doesn't work also on VirtualBox drivers.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
- Current behavior: Godot crashes at startup without any useful information.
- Expected behavior: Godot runs on this platform, because it can run there. Otherwise show information about incompatible OpenGL driver and close without crash.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Run Godot and expect crash on OpenGL 2.1 on Windows.

**Additional information:**

On Linux and Mesa OpenGL 2.1 drivers - Godot works properly (on the same hardware), because Mesa is new and Mesa is cheating :)

As far I found 11 function which are compatible with GLES 2.0 and OpenGL 3.0 (not OpenGL 2.1):
- `glGenFramebuffers`,
- `glGenerateMipmap`,
- `glGenRenderbuffers`,
- `glBindRenderbuffer`,
- `glBindFramebuffer`,
- `glCheckFramebufferStatus`,
- `glDeleteRenderbuffers`,
- `glDeleteFramebuffers`,
- `glFramebufferTexture2D`,
- `glRenderbufferStorage`,
- `glFramebufferRenderbuffer`.

Every function listed above are supported with "EXT" suffix (e.g. `glGenerateMipmapEXT`). Replacing it in `rasterizer_gles2.cpp` allows Godot to run and play/edit 2D game on old Intel driver (VirtualBox shows white window and GLSL link error in console, but doesn't crash).

Godot should use functions with `EXT` suffix for OpenGL < 3.0 and it should check every pointer on initialization (instead of checking the OpenGL version).

data.title: Equivalent to CanvasModulate that only affects child nodes.
data.body:
CanvasModulate is an odd beast that only affects parallax layers or the whole scene when tinting. It'd be really useful to have a similar node that tints every node child node of it and only the child nodes.
Using groups is kind of annoying (and might be far from optimal in performance) for this, specially when using stuff like sprites made out of multiple parts.

data.title: Cannot compile for Android on Windows with NDK in a path with spaces
data.body:
Windows 10 64bit, trying to compile current master

Basically I've stumbled upon something similar to #1403 where os_android.os wouldn't get created, but ending with a different message: "The system could not find the path specified".
The solution was to rename `C:\Program Files (x86)\Android\android-ndk-r12b\toolchains\arm-linux-androideabi-4.9\prebuilt\windows` to `(...)\windows-x86_64`.

Indeed I've downloaded the 32bit NDK, but appearantly the buldsystem only expects the 64bit NDK (on a 64bit system) no matter what. Probably should be fixed (couldn't compile for Android on Windows otherwise).

Would it be possible to be able to scroll by holding middle-click and zoom horizontally by using the wheel?

data.title: Fix crash when disabling main screen plugin
Scene importer doesn't make use of imported texture files
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Debian GNU/Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Importing a collada results in a .scn file, and additional .tex files. It appears that the importer-generated .scn file doesn't make use of these .tex files; instead, it stores an additional internal copy of the textures data within the .scn file, and I'm not entirely sure but this data might even be uncompressed (judging by the file sizes, more on this below).

I expected that the generated .scn file would make use of generated .tex file. Furthermore, I wouldn't expect any non-compressed texture data to be stored anywhere.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I tested this with a Better Collada Exporter generated .dae file, which uses 4 textures:
- Using VRAM compression, it created 5 texture files totaling around 22MBs and a .scn file around 34MB.
- Using WebP compression, it created 5 texture files totaling around 800KB and a .scn file again around 34MB.
- After editing the materials in the scene with Godot to use the generated .tex files, the .scn file reduced to ~2MB.

I tested this with a totally different dae file, with similar results.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Add Array.last()
data.body:
Currently, to get the last element of an array we have to write `array[array.size()-1]`, which is a bit tedious given how many times this case happens.
Could we have an `array.last()` method like STL does with `back()`?

data.title: FXAA applied multiple times in UI
data.body:
![fxaaproblem](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6635630/18718432/7c7a20c6-7ff1-11e6-87bc-d489f365e718.png)

In the top image, there are thicker blur parts.

In the bottom image, there are thinner blur parts characteristic of a lightweight FXAA implementation.

The top image is obviously incorrect and represents no known version of FXAA.

The issue seems to be that FXAA is applied to the whole rendering surface rather than just to a 3D camera. It's a very subtle difference, but the current pipeline makes FXAA kind of funny in some cases. What are those cases?

The top image is a screenshot from the editor in which the scene node tree looks like this:

> WorldEnvironment with FXAA
> 
> > Stuff

This problem may also surface >>>ingame<<< in cases like:

> Scene
> 
> > Viewport
> > 
> > > Camera

What is happening? Here is what is happening:

Godot is like, "You want to render a scene, and you want FXAA? Okay, here's FXAA. Now you want that scene in a viewport, and you want FXAA? Okay, here's FXAA."

Bottom line, FXAA should only be applied once.

This issue was hinted at in #654 before but the discussion was less extensive.

data.title: drop_data is called only if can_drop_data is true
data.body:
Godot 2.2 on Debian testing.

If I drop something where can_drop_data return false, drop_data is not called, so I can't know when I drop something where I can't.
